sen.j: 『後撰和歌集・巻第十七・雑三』、1219番の詞書と付記によれば、筑紫国の白河という所に住んでいた「名高く、事好む女」で、大宰大弐・藤原興範に水を汲むよう乞われると、「年ふればわが黒髪も白河の みづはくむまで老いにけるかも」と詠んだという。
sen.e: According to the Kotobagaki (foreword) and additional remarks of No. 1219, "Gosen Wakashu (the second of the Imperial anthologies of classical Waka poetry) Vol. 17, Miscellaneous 3", she was a "famous, tasteful woman" who lived in a place called Shirakawa in the Tsukushi Province; when FUJIWARA no Okinari, a dazai daini (senior assistant governor-general of Government Headquarters in Kyushu), asked her to fetch water, she is to said to have composed a poem which reads, "Toshifureba, wagakurokamimo, Shirakawano, mizuhakumadeni oinikerukamo" (Time has passed and my once black hair has turned white, and I have fallen so low that now I have to fetch water from Shirakawa River myself).

sen.e: She formed a friendship with KIYOHARA no Motosuke, and when she gave him a send-off upon his return to Kyoto after completion of his term as a Higo no kami (governor of Higo Province), she composed a poem which reads, "Shirakawano, sokonomizuhite, chiritatamu, tokinizo kimiwo, omoiwasuren" (I will not forget you even if the water of Shirakawa River dries up).
